Below is the email I received about my UN money. I don't want it but if you'd like you are welcome to it. Since they didn't seem to know my name or anything, I guess its available to anyone who supplies the 'info' they want, emoticon_xdonno 
 
 
 UNITED NATIONS (UN) DEBT
 RECONCILIATION DEPARTMENT. 
 GENEVA-SWITZERLAND.
 
 OUR REF: UN-0xx2/987/2008
 Chairman Committee On Foreign 
 Contract And Inheritance fund Payment Notification

 Sir. Eric Ben.
 Attn: Sir /Madam

 The British Prime Minister in conjunction with U.S.A GOVERNMENT, WORLD BANK AND UNITED NATIONS ORGANIZATION do hereby give this irrevocable approval order with This Release Code: GNC/3480/02/08 In Your Favor For Your Contract Entitlement And Your Inheritance Fund Which You Have Not Received Yet, Now It Was Approved By The World Bank, That Your Contract/Inheritance Fund should be released through UNITED NATIONS ORGANIZATION. So You Are Advised To Present Any Of Your Choice, On How You Want To Receive Your Fund, Either By BANK DRAFT OR BY ATM CARD OR WIRE TRANSFER, So In Regards To The Transfer You Can Provide Any Of Your BANK ACCOUNT DETAILS For The Transfer Of Your Fund With Out Delay. I Am Contacting You In Regards To The Instruction Given By United Nations, Please I Will Urge You To Try And Indicate On How You Want Your Fund To Be Released To You From The Three Options Above.
 Now your new Payment, United nations Approval No; UN5685P, White House Approved No: WH44CV, Reference No.-35460021, Allocation No: 674632 Password No: 339331, Pin Code No: 55674 and your Certificate of Merit Payment No: 103, Released Code No: 0763; Immediate Citibank Telex confirmation No: -1114433; Secret Code No: XXTN013, Having received these vital payment number, therefore You are qualified now to received and confirm Your payment with the United Nation immediately within the next 72hrs.
 As a matter of fact, you are required to Deal and Communicate only with MR. ROBERT BISCHOFF, HEAD OF INTERNATIONAL REMMITTANCE CITIBANK, UNITED KINGDOM, with the help of monitory team from the CITIBANK OF NEW YORK which is our official remitting bank, Committee On Foreign Payment Matters in United Nations, has look up to make sure you receive your Fund.
 So contact: MR ROBERT BISCHOFF on his contact information, Direct Citibank , Telephone Number: +447903517790, Email:( robertbischoffremittacitibank@perpignan.net ) . For immediate release of your contract/inheritance/Award Winning claim be informed that you are not allowed to correspond with any person or office anymore, you are
 required to send bellow information for your transfer.
 1) YOUR FULL NAME:
 2) ADDRESS, CITY, STATE AND COUNTRY:
 3) PERSONAL CELL PHONE, FAX AND MOBILE:

 10) COPY OF YOUR INT'L PASSPORT/DRIVERS LICENSE:
 Note: Your Personal Contact/Communication Code With Citibank Is (011), You Are Advice To Send Your Full Banking Information To The Citibank London, International Remittance Director Headed By Mr. Robert Bischoff And Make Sure You Speak With Him, With Your New Payment Code For The Release Of Your Payment And Send To Him All Your Banking Information Now.

 Sir. Eric Ben.

post_info.post_title: You can have this free money I won from the UN!

yup
 
 http://internetscamphishing.blogspot.com/2008/01/united-nations-citi-bank-scam.html
 
 Seemed like an obvious scam.
 
 But MR. ROBERT BISCHOFF does exist and did work for CENTER BANCORP INC in 2001.

Scams like that have been emailed to people all over the world for years. Many of them originated in Nigeria where the language of the "story" was perfected and blanketed to many recipients. Any one fool enough to give their personal bank information to someone requesting it by email deserves to be bilked of their money.
 
 These people will use a real event, such as a death they read about in the paper, to provide the background story regarding where the money will come from. The use of real names and conditions of death is part of their attempt to prove authenticity.
 
 I have two rules regarding such things:
 
 1
 Never give personal info in response to an email request for it. Your bank will not contact you by email. The government will not contact you by email.
 
 2
 If you ever have to pay a fee to collect a prize, you're not really going to get the prize...you're going to get robbed. If someone says you have won something, tell them to send it to you.
LOL, you're right Jim. Anyone dumb enough to 'pay' for a prize or give out personal info deserves it!!!

Speaking of scams, I just received this offer to be an International Agent. Anyone looking for a job?
 From: "SHANGHAI JIA FENG CO. LTD." <ceo@fengcoltd.com< 
 Subject: your service is needed
 Date: Wed, 9 Apr 2008 16:04:30 +0300 (IDT)
 To: 
 Dear Sir/Madam,
 
 Our company SHANGHAI JIA FENG CO. LTD, require the
 services of
 international agents if you are interested in this
 position reply for
 more information.
 
 Regards,
 Jia Feng
 CEO (SHANGHAI JIA FENG CO. LTD.)
 Isn't it ironic that the asian term for mugging, or robbing someone is to shanghai them. emoticon_xgood emoticon_xkill

2
 If you ever have to pay a fee to collect a prize, you're not really going to get the prize...you're going to get robbed. If someone says you have won something, tell them to send it to you.

 
 There are exceptions to this, usually when the prize has certain conditions attached that make it very difficult to use. I encountered an incidence of this when I was told I had won a holiday, I knew it wasn't going to be all it seemed but I shelled out the 20p for a second class stamp and got the brochure. Turns out I could have the holiday (for a GBP34 "handling fee") but I couldn't choose the dates I went. The way they made money with this one was a premium rate phone line to find out the information I got through the post. Most people are too dumb to read the small print that tells them they don't have to use the number.

Isn't it ironic that the asian term for mugging, or robbing someone is to shanghai them.

 
 As far as I know, it's not an asian term. It's a western term, apparently originating in the idea of one evening getting drugged and waking up in the morning on a ship bound for Shanghai.
 
 I doubt Asians would use a term like that :)
 
 As for the 419's, it's sometimes amusing to see how they evolve. Wherever a crysis comes up, the letters soon follow. I laughed out loud when I got one from Iraq's minister of some whatever...
 
 Also, I read some funny articles about how people who got spam mails decided to answer for fun, leading the spammer on a wild goose chase. I remember one almost got the spammer to convert his religion...
 
 They really should not work any more, but you know how it is. To send out 5 million spam mails costs you almost nothing, and even if only one in a milion bite for one payment...
